frameDefinitions: These are words describing a basic commercial transaction involving a Buyer and a Seller exchanging Money and Goods, taking the perspective of the Buyer.
The Authorities hold a Suspect under suspicion of having committed a crime (Charges).
In this frame, a Booker brings about a situation where an Organization plans to provide Services to a Client at a particular Scheduled_time.
A Speaker mentions a Specified_entity filling a Role, thereby providing information which supports a point of the Speaker.
A Lessee gains the use of Goods owned by a Lessor by payment to the Lessor.
Authorities charge a Suspect, who is under suspicion of having committed a crime (the Charges), and take him/her into custody.'
frameExamples: Abby bought a car from Robin for $5,000.
The police <t>held</t> Mr. Smith in the slammer on charges of killing his lawyer.
We can <t>book</t> you a boatride on the Somme or a special tour of the Louvre .
He cites the chief original observations <t>adduced</t> by Darwin as evidence for his theory.
We are <t>renting</t> our apartment from a kind man named Tom.
The police <t>arrested</t> Harry on charges of manslaughter.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Buyer</fen> wants the <fen>Goods</fen> and offers <fen>Money</fen> to a <fen>Seller</fen> in exchange for them.
The role <fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor or time, for example) which is exchanged for <fen>Money</fen> in a transaction.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Authorities</fen> hold the <fen>Suspect</fen> in custody.
This role identifies the person who is taken into custody and held, under suspicion of having committed a crime.
When the detaining occurs.
Where the detaining takes place.
The entity that is intended to receive the <fen>Services</fen> of the <fen>Organization</fen>.
The goods or labor that the <fen>Client</fen> requests the <fen>Organization</fen> preserve for future consumption or rendering.
The entity that enters into its records the request of the <fen>Client</fen> to retain <fen>Services</fen> in the future.
The future point in time when the <fen>Client</fen> arranges for the <fen>Organization</fen> to provide <fen>Services</fen>.
The entity that contacts the <fen>Organization</fen> directly.  In many if not most cases, a <fen>Booker</fen> is also a <fen>Client</fen>, but the roles may also be separated, e.g. a travel agent.
The time at which the reserving event takes place.
The location the <fen>Booker</fen> performs the action.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who specifies the <fen>Role</fen> to be filled by the <fen>Specified_entity</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The entity that the <fen>Speaker</fen> identifies as filling a particular <fen>Role</fen>.
A slot in a particular or generic event or relation whose filler the <fen>Speaker</fen> identifies.
The time when the statement is made.
The role specifies the place where the statement takes place.
The individual that gains temporary use of the <fen>Goods</fen> by paying the <fen>Lessor</fen>
The role <fen>Goods</fen> is an item which is temporarily exchanged for <fen>Money</fen> in a transaction.
When the event occurs.
The location the renting takes place.
<fen>Charges</fen> identifies a category within the legal system; it is the crime with which the <fen>Suspect</fen> is charged.
The <fen>Authorities</fen> charge the <fen>Suspect</fen> with commiting a crime, and take him/her into custody.
The <fen>Suspect</fen> is taken into custody, under suspicion of having committed a crime.
<fen>Offense</fen> identifies the ordinary language use of the reason for which a <fen>Suspect</fen> is arrested.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the arrest occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the arrest occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Jess</fex> bought a coat.
Only one winner purchased <fex>the paintings</fex>
Phil Collins booked his <fex>cockatoo</fex> into a $350-a-night pet hotel.
She reserved the room for the meeting <fex>for Tuesday</fex> .
The hotel reserved two rooms for me .
I booked the room for Monday <fex>only on Tuesday</fex> .
But<fex>Arturo Boncato Jr., marketing manager of the Marco Polo Hotel,</fex> cited the high occupancy rates in the hotels as proof of increasing visitors' confidence.
<fex>In a subsequent paper</fex> he adduced further evidence.

Reilly pointed <fex>to the high labor costs</fex> as the
main reason for the decision to close down the New Orleans facility.
TCI named the overly expensive bid price <fex>as the main reason for their strict opposition against a merger</fex>.

Persistent, heavy rainfall and poorly maintained drainage systems were cited
<fex>yesterday</fex> as the prime causes for the rising floodwaters
<fex>In Kuala Lumpur</fex>, he also pointed to the accountability/assessment arena as a place for new businesses to investigate.
<fex>We</fex> 've been renting from him for years .
I tried to hire <fex>a bicycle</fex> .
I rented the car <fex>right next to the airport</fex> .
The police arrested Harry <fex>on charges of manslaughter</fex>.
<fex>The police</fex> arrested Harry on charges of manslaughter.
The police arrested <fex>Harry</fex> on charges of manslaughter.
They arrested Harry <fex>for shoplifting</fex>.
The police arrested Harry <fex>on Wednesday afternoon</fex>.
The police arrested Harry <fex>in front of his house</fex>.
